title: Laser assisted cold spray of AISI 4340 steel

extractedText.notes: Cold spray (CS) deposit without any laser heating.
Laser‐assisted cold spray (LACS) deposit created with in situ laser heating to achieve a substrate surface temperature of 500°C; this deposit exhibited the lowest measured hardness.
LACS deposit produced at a surface temperature of 738°C under the higher gas temperature/pressure condition (approx. 550°C and 4.14 MPa), yielding an average hardness of 532 HV.
LACS deposit at 738°C when the gas temperature and pressure were lowered (approx. 475°C and 3.1 MPa), resulting in an increased average hardness of 592 HV.
LACS deposit produced at a surface temperature of 950°C; the microhardness returned to a value similar to the original CS deposit.

title: A 4340 Steel with Superior Strength and Toughness Achieved by Heterostructure via Intercritical Quenching and Tempering
On the Role of Deformation and Cracking in the Cold Spray Processing of Refractory Ta Powders Onto Ta or 4340 Steel Substrates: Effects of Topical Oxide Layers and Spray Velocity

extractedText.notes: Cold spray processing of Ta powders on Ta substrate: experiments and simulations revealed oxide layer formation (∼2.8 nm) and splat microstructure with associated oxide cracking.

Cold spray processing of Ta powders on 4340 steel substrate: simulations indicate high impact‐induced temperatures (above steel’s recrystallization temperature) and associated oxide cracking, suggesting potential for diffusion bonding.

title: Evaluation of the Fatigue Behavior and Failure Mechanisms of 4340 Steel Coated with WIP-C1 (Ni/CrC) by Cold Spray

extractedText.notes: Fatigue behavior of AISI 4340 steel coated with WIP-C1 by cold spray (using a VRC Gen-III machine) was evaluated; tensile properties were measured per ASTM E8/E8M-16.

title: Microstructural and Tribological Properties of High-Performance Inconel 625 alloy-WS2 Salf-Lubricious Composite Coating By Laser Assisted Cold Spray

extractedText.feedstock_material_composition: Cr 20–23 wt%, Mo 8–10 wt%, Mn 0.5 wt%, Nb 3.15–4.15 wt%, Fe 5 wt%, Ni Balance
extractedText.notes: Self‐lubricious composite coating of Inconel 625 blended with WS2 was deposited on AISI 304 stainless steel using laser assisted cold spray (LACS) at 700W laser power, 60 mm/min scanning speed, and 15bar gas pressure. The process maintained the deposition temperature below the WS2 evaporation point, yielding a coating with high hardness and excellent tribological performance.

title: Towards High-Strength Cold Spray Additive Manufactured Metals: Methods, Mechanisms, and Properties

extractedText.notes: Al 6061 deposit produced using heat‐treated powders shows an increase in UTS from 70 to 107 MPa with ductility reported as <0.2%. Also, the strength of the powder itself drops from 311 to 179 MPa after heat treatment.
In‐situ micro‐forging assisted cold spray of an Fe deposit using preheated powders yields a UTS of 145.17 MPa – 53.90% higher than deposits with non‐heated powders.
An Inconel 718 deposit made by in‐situ micro‐forging assisted cold spray exhibits a UTS of 463 MPa, ductility of 0.48%, and a hardness of 507 HV.
Friction stir processing (FSP) applied to a cold‐sprayed Cu deposit raises the UTS from 83 MPa to 310 MPa and improves elongation from <1% to 40%.
Hot rolling of an Al 380 alloy deposit increases tensile strength from 100 MPa to 420 MPa while elongation improves from <2% to >10%.

title: Effect of Particle Morphology on Cold Spray Deposition of Chromium Carbide-Nickel Chromium Cermet Powders
Cold Spray Coatings of Complex Concentrated Alloys: Critical Assessment of Milestones, Challenges, and Opportunities
Laser assisted cold spray of ferritic alloys: oxide dispersion strengtherened fe91ni8zr1 and aisi 4340 steel
Understanding the Effect of Substrate Preheating Temperature and Track Spacing on Laser Assisted Cold Spraying of Ti6Al4V

extractedText.notes: Standard cold spray specimen deposited without laser substrate preheating; average microhardness measured at 429 HV.

LACS specimen (Phase2) deposited on a mill‐annealed Ti6Al4V substrate preheated to 600°C with a 1 mm track spacing; showed higher scatter with some interface values (~455 HV) but an overall average of 403 HV.
LACS specimen (Phase2) deposited on a mill‐annealed Ti6Al4V substrate preheated to 600°C with a 2 mm track spacing; exhibited an even deposit distribution with an average hardness of 397 HV.
LACS specimen (Phase2) deposited on a mill‐annealed Ti6Al4V substrate preheated to 600°C with a 3 mm track spacing; exhibited a slightly lower average hardness of 388 HV.

title: Structural Analysis and Mechanical properties of Some Coatings Obtained by Cold Spray Method. A Review

extractedText.notes: Cold spray coating applied using a preliminary WIP-BC1 bonding layer followed by spraying with WIP-C1 powder; resulted in an increase in hardness from 17 HRC (base) to 40–44 HRC.
Low‐pressure cold spray deposition with WC–Ni powder (4% Ni variant) on a mild steel substrate produced a maximum hardness of 459.2 HV.

A comparative study of cold spray versus HVOF on SA516 boiler steel using Ni–Cr powders showed cold spray deposits with hardness ranging from 456 to 601 HV (averaging ~529 HV) and improved scratch resistance.

title: Corrosion properties of Cold-Sprayed Tantalum Coatings

extractedText.notes: Cold-sprayed tantalum coating (CS Ta1) prepared using standard powder (Amperit 150.090) with the Kinetiks3000 system on a grit-blasted steel substrate; exhibited through-porosity and lower corrosion resistance.

Cold-sprayed tantalum coating (CS Ta2) prepared using improved powder (Amperit 151.065) with the Kinetiks4000 system on a grit-blasted steel substrate; exhibited a dense, pore‐free microstructure with corrosion resistance similar to that of bulk tantalum.

title: Effect of Substrate Surface Roughening and Cold Spray Coating On The Fatigue Life of AA2024 specimens

extractedText.notes: Cold spray coating experiments were conducted by depositing commercially pure (CP) Al powder onto AA2024-T351 aluminum alloy substrates. The substrate mechanical properties, as detailed in Table 1, are provided.

title: Laser Assisted Cold Spray Deposition
Cold Spray and Laser-Assisted Cold Spray of CrMnCoFeNi High Entropy Alloy Using Nitrogen as the Propelling Gas

extractedText.notes: Cold spray deposition using nitrogen as the process gas at 950°C and 4.9 MPa produced coatings up to 250 μm thick on three different substrates, though weak inter‐particle bonding was observed.

Laser‐assisted cold spray (LACS) deposition on mild steel using a 4 kW continuous fiber laser (with process parameters approx. T = 500°C and P = 3.4 MPa) enhanced inter‐particle bonding and led to a higher measured coating hardness.

title: Influence of Surface Temperature in the Laser Assisted Cold Spray Deposition of Sequential Oxide Dispersion Strengthened Layers: Microstructure and Hardness

extractedText.notes: LACS deposit at 650°C with 6 layers; ferritic phase with refined grain structure; hardness measured as 598 ±56 HV.
LACS deposit at 950°C with 6 layers; austenitic phase with coarser grains; hardness measured as 293 ±38 HV.

title: Particle Deformation and Microstructure Evolution During Cold Spray of Individual Al-Cu Alloy Powder particles

extractedText.notes: Cold spray deposition of Al-2Cu alloy powder particles onto 4340 steel; compression ratio ~0.59 observed and microstructure evolution analyzed.
Cold spray deposition of Al-3Cu alloy particles onto 4340 steel; features such as jetting and peripheral particle deposition were noted.
Cold spray deposition of Al-4Cu alloy particles onto 4340 steel; particle morphologies with fractures and peripheral features were observed.
Cold spray deposition of Al-5Cu alloy particles onto 4340 steel; average compression ratio ~0.55 observed with ultrafine grain formation at the interface.
Cold spray deposition of pure aluminum particles using nitrogen as carrier gas onto 4340 steel; high deformation observed with nanohardness ~1.0 GPa.
Cold spray deposition of pure copper particles using nitrogen as carrier gas onto 4340 steel; lower deformation observed with nanohardness ~1.8 GPa.

title: Improving Inter-Particle Deformation and Bonding by Preserving Transient in-situ Deposition Temperatures During Cold Spray
How to Unleash the Remarkable Potential of Cold Spray: A Perspective
Interfacial Contact and Deformation: From All Solid State Li Batteries to the Cold Spray Refractory Ta Powders

extractedText.experiment_type: Cold Spray Processing of Refractory Ta Powders

substrates.topical_oxide: Not separately characterized; presumed similar to particle oxide

cold_spray_parameters.temperature_effects: FEM simulations show a significant local temperature rise (Ta–Ta impact shows higher temperature due to Ta’s lower heat capacity; Ta on 4340 steel yields temperatures above the substrate’s recrystallization threshold, promoting possible diffusion bonding)
cold_spray_parameters.contact_and_deformation: Simulations and experiments reveal formation of splat microstructures, high equivalent plastic strains localized to the contact zone, and both axial and shear strains that can result in brittle cracking of the oxide layers

extractedText.observations: Increasing impact velocity and thicker oxide layers lead to a lower fraction of unfractured oxide; cracking of the nanoscale oxide is critical to expose bare metal surfaces for bonding; overall, controlled deformation and cracking via cold spray enable improved interfacial contact and potential metallurgical bonding on both Ta and 4340 steel substrates

title: Residual Stress in Cold Spray SS304L Measured Via Neutron Diffraction and Comparison of Analytical Models to Predict the Residual Stress

extractedText.notes: Cold spray experiments used SS304L powder (composition in Table 1) deposited onto a cold-rolled SS304L plate. Neutron diffraction was employed to map residual stresses, and mechanical tests on the substrate showed a yield strength of 270 MPa. As‐sprayed deposits exhibited a uniform hardness of ~400 HV, while laser heating modified the near‐surface stress state and hardness profile.

title: Influence of Deposition Technology on the Morphology of Chromium Carbide-Based Powder Coatings

extractedText.notes: Cold Spray coating deposited using a VRC Gen-III cold spray machine with WIP-C1 powder on AISI 4340 steel; XRD analysis showed a predominant NiCr phase and a secondary CrC phase with minimal oxidation.

title: Laser Assisted Cold Spray of Aluminum Alloy 6061: Experimental Results

extractedText.notes: Control condition (TS-0kW-T): Cold spray deposition of Al6061 powder on an Al6061-T6 substrate without laser assistance or extra heating, resulting in low ultimate tensile strength and very low elongation.

Intermediate condition (TS-3kW-H): Laser-assisted cold spray using 3 kW laser power with substrate heating (hotplate), yielding a marked increase in tensile strength compared to the control, with moderate deposit softening.

Enhanced condition (TS-5kW-H): Laser-assisted cold spray with 5 kW laser power and hotplate backing, producing a high spray spot temperature (~455°C) that causes significant intersplat bonding, deposit softening, and marked improvements in both tensile strength and ductility.
